title: Grab the brolly, prepare for a battering
text:
Rain and storms set to batter parts of Australia, while Hobart and Adelaide swelter through heatwave February 28, 2017 9:21am Sunrise at Bondi after a night of heavy rain. More is on the way this week. Picture: John Grainger Debra Killalea news.com.au @DebKillalea 
GRAB the brolly and get set for a whole lot of rain. 
Showers and storms are set to hit large parts of Australia over the next few days with Queensland and NSW bracing for a battering. 
While parts of southeastern Australia endures a sweltering heatwave, the Bureau of Meteorology has painted a very different picture for the rest of the country. 
Showers and storms are predicted for parts the west coast, right up across the Top End and down to the NSW/Victorian border. 
Perth, Adelaide, Melbourne and Hobart will remain mostly hot and dry but Sydney and Brisbane in particular have been warned to expect heavy falls today and further rain into next week. Showers and storms this afternoon around the country. Possible heavy falls #QLD #NSW . Local forecasts https://t.co/ByG5YyVjFH pic.twitter.com/yOg6BbtSTl — BOM Australia (@BOM_au) February 27, 2017 
SYDNEY/CANBERRA 
Showers are forecast to hit much of the state’s coastlines this week, with the BoM warning Sydney can expect four seasons in one day as the city marches into autumn. The rains are here in a big way with a chance of showers across a lot of Australia, while a heatwave hits parts of SA, Tas and Vic. Picture: Bureau of Meteorology Source: Supplied 
A coastal trough is bringing a whole heap of rain in the coming days with a high chance of showers and storms right up until next Monday. 
Sydney can except a top of 26C today with storms, 26C tomorrow and 26C on Thursday. 
Canberra can expect a top of 28C today and 29C tomorrow with showers forecast right up until Monday. Coastal trough to bring showers to eastern #NSW for remainder of the week. Pack the brolly! #NSWweather https://t.co/nNfJLBJ0Kf pic.twitter.com/4JOQKs2ARA — BOM New South Wales (@BOM_NSW) February 27, 2017 
BRISBANE 
Those living in the capital of the Sunshine State better arm themselves with a big umbrella because there’s a heap of rain on the way — and it’s sticking around. 
Heavy showers are predicted for today and tomorrow with a maximum of 28C and 29C. 
Further rain is expected throughout the weekend and up until Monday. 
The stormy conditions come as temperatures in Brisbane dip below a 30C maximum for the first time in a month. You weren't in #LaLaLand today in #Brisbane , it was below 30C for the first time since Jan 27th! Showers & poss storms for #SEQld tomorrow. — BOM Queensland (@BOM_Qld) February 27, 2017 Amanda Nugent of Brisbane uses her beach umbrella as shelter from the Rain. Picture Mike Batterham Source: News Corp Australia 
ADELAIDE 
As summer is on track to be the warmest on record for many parts of NSW and southern QLD, those living in South Australia are sweltering. 
Adelaide is bracing for a top of 37C today, 37C tomorrow with the mercury to stay around the mid to low 30s until Monday. 
The city also had its warmest minimum temperature overnight with 27.5°C recorded, making it the warmest February night since 15 February 2015. SA forecast for the week - Hot & sunny. #GroundhogDay #SummerNotOverYet — BOM South Australia (@BOM_SA) February 27, 2017 
MELBOURNE 
Victoria is also enduring hot conditions with Melbourne set to hit a high of 34C today, 31C tomorrow and 29C on Thursday. 
But showers are forecast for Friday with a top of 27C before temperatures dip to the mid 20s by Monday. The highest summer temp in @Melbourne this year was 38.2°C. This is the lowest maximum summer temp since 01/02. https://t.co/tRSEVZCofx — BOM Victoria (@BOM_Vic) February 27, 2017 
TASMANIA 
Those living in the Apple Isle have been experiencing hotter than average conditions, so much so it is experiencing a heatwave. 
Hobart is braced for a top of 27C today, and 28C tomorrow. Further inland the Upper Derwent Valley can expect 31C. 
While 28C doesn’t sound like a lot for those living in warmer states, it signifies heatwave conditions further south. 
The definition of a heatwave is a run of days above the average maximum temperature for that time of year. In Hobart, in high summer that’s just 22C. Warm and mostly sunny in #Tasmania today. Mid/high 20's tomorrow, with 31°C expected in the Upper Derwent Valley. https://t.co/iFnJf8J7XX pic.twitter.com/rvjkf2JT60 — BOM Tasmania (@BOM_Tas) February 27, 2017 
PERTH 
While showers and storms are predicted for northern parts of the state, the mercury isn’t dipping in Perth. 
The city can expect 34C today, 36C tomorrow and 33C on Friday. 
The temperatures will remain in the mid to high 30s throughout the weekend until Monday. 
DARWIN 
Things are looking very hot and stormy across the Top End. 
Darwin can expect a top of 34C today and 34C tomorrow with storms and rain expected. 
Conditions are likely to remain hot across the weekend and until Monday with further storms and temperatures in the low 30Cs predicted. 50 mm at #Darwin airport takes Feb's total to approx 600, well above the average of 371 but a long way shy of 1110 mm in 2011 from TC Carlos pic.twitter.com/xl81lA7ACx
